chapter.title: Pre-Distribution: Testing Accessibility Tools
chapter.para: This chapter is for OS distribution testers and outlines how to verify the functionality of GNOME accessibility tools prior to releasing new OS distributions.

Thank you for taking the time and care to better understand what you need to do to help ensure accessibility works on your distribution. This chapter provides some very high level things you can do to quickly verify that various aspects of GNOME accessibility work on your operating system distribution.

section.title: Test Speech
section.para: Orca uses GNOME Speech for speech synthesis.

step.para: Run the test-speech application by opening a terminal window (Alt-F1 - Applications - Accessories - Terminal) and typing test-speech Enter.

A list of speech synthesis engines should be displayed. These may include eSpeak, Festival and others. Enter the number corresponding to the speech synthesizer engines you need to test. Ideally, no errors will be encountered. If you have no servers listed or errors are being listed, confirm you have included all the required packages for your OS build.
Use the various tests listed by the speech engine to confirm speech and audio output.

Verify that speech works in conjunction with other audio output applications like Movie Player or Rhythmbox Music Player. If the two audio sources can't be heard simultaneously, consider the following:

listitem.para: Shipping a speech synthesis engine with your operating system, such as eSpeak
Including gnome-speech and the GNOME Speech driver for the speech synthesis engine(s) you choose to ship
Exploring how to make audio work better on your distribution, especially audio mixing

section.title: Test Braille
section.para: Orca uses BrlTTY and liblouis for Braille output.

step.para: Verify BrlTTY by opening a new terminal window and typing brltty -d /dev/term/0 -bxw -xno -p none -A auth=none -n. A little BrlTTY window should appear. If the BrlTTY window doesn't appear, or any errors are shown, then you have some work to do.
Ensure the Python bindings for BrlTTY are installed by typing python -c "import brlapi" - if it produces errors, you probably don't have the Python bindings installed.
Ensure liblouis is installed by typing [ TBD ] in a terminal window.
Test if BrlTTY automatically starts when a USB Braille device is plugged in.

section.title: Test Magnification
section.para: Orca uses GNOME Mag for magnification. For a compelling magnification experience, GNOME Mag uses various X Windows System server extensions: COMPOSITE, FIXES, DAMAGE, RANDR, and RENDER.

step.para: Verify GNOME Mag works by opening a terminal window and typing magnifier -h. The magnifier should come up in split-screen mode.

Run Orca and open the Magnifier preferences tab in the Preferences GUI. Enable magnification by selecting the checkbox at the top of the magnifier preferences tab. The magnifier should come up in full-screen mode by default. If it doesn't, you might not have the appropriate X Windows System server extensions installed/enabled, or you might be running into some odd conflict with a compositing manager, such as Compiz. If you're using Compiz, try going back to Metacity and starting over.

section.title: Test AT-SPI
section.para: Orca uses the AT-SPI to communicate with applications on the desktop.

step.para: Enable assistive technologies for your login session. You should be able to do this by checking the "Enable assistive technologies" checkbox in the "Assistive Technologies" preferences dialog and then logging out and back in again. If you're bold and really want to do the right thing, you can ship with accessibility enabled by default for your distribution. This can be done by modifying the default gconf values:

Login with accessibility enabled. You should not get any errors. Check xprop -root | grep AT_SPI_IOR. If you don't see an AT_SPI_IOR property on your root window, then something is wrong with your infrastructure. The usual cause of this is not setting the --libexecdir properly when building AT-SPI. Search the Orca WIKI Download/Install page for libexecdir for more information.

section.title: Test Orca
section.para: Do a quick test of Orca to ensure things are not seriously broken.

step.para: Run orca -no-setup. Orca should come up speaking and the main window should appear.
Tab across the buttons in the Orca main window. They should speak as you tab between them.
Press AltF1 to make the GNOME "Start" menu appear. Arrow up and down in the menu items. Orca should speak them as you move between them.
Press AltTab to switch between windows. Orca should speak the window titles.
